text: ♪ [music] ♪

- [Interviewer] We sit here in Chicago,
and we're at GOTO Chicago, which is a software developer conference.

And I'm really happy that we have two
guests in the studio here, Evan and Jill.

And we made up some cool questions. We think it's relevant for people
to hear the discussions we have here.

So why don't we just start with you, Jill? If you can just say a little bit
about yourself, your background,

and, yeah, what we're going to talk about. - [Jill] Sure. Yeah. So I got my start as a software
engineer, I worked at salesforce.com.

So I was there for seven years. I was working on a lot of platform features,
so external developers as customers.

Around, sort of, last year at Salesforce,
I became an engineering manager.

The management was very, very intriguing to me. I felt like people problems were more
interesting to me than computer problems.

And that was sort of the
responsibilities I was gravitating towards. While I was at Salesforce, I helped
start the Women in Technology
Employee Resource Group there. After that, went to a social media company.

I was an engineering manager there, also working
with the women in engineering group.

And then after that, I wound up at Lyft. So I've been at Lyft for about four years. Was initially hired to build
up the infrastructure engineering org.

So I built that from about 7 people to 115. So quite a large org through hyper-growth,
and have been doing a lot of diversity

and inclusion-related work at Lyft
for pretty much the entirety of my tenure.

So last year, I wound up pitching a job
role to my boss and to our founders.

And I became the director
of engineering leadership development. And I view my role as in service
to three different groups.

One is our manager population. I want to make our managers
better at managing, and specifically better at managing
underrepresented people.

I also want to be in service to our engineers
as well and to our individual contributors

and help usher them into leadership roles. And then I also view myself in service
to the external community as well.

So that's the work that I've been
doing for the last year or so. - And that's also why you're here. - That's exactly why I'm here, yeah.

- Thank you for coming. - Yeah. Thank you for having me. - So Evan, you have a way different background. Maybe you can just tell a little about that,
how you ended up sitting here.

- [Evan] Yeah. My story is a little bit different. It gets started after I spent, you know,
three months living in a hut in the forest in a monastery.

And I guess, after that experience, learning
the tools of mindfulness and learning just how to slow down, I came back and wanted
to share those experiences with other people.

So I wrote a book and then from that book,
I organically started doing talks in schools and companies, just getting, you know,
teaching people the skills and tools

to live their best most vibrant lives. And while doing that, I got
involved in some really cool initiatives,

you know, some environmental
campaigns to ban single-use plastic bags, you know, engaged education movement
with disadvantaged children upon which I illustrated

my children's stories to learn
literary skills in a fun and dynamic way. And then I guess more related to this,
a social enterprise in a favela in Brazil

to teach people to people the skills
of entrepreneurship to create alternative pathways to the drug and crime trade down there.

It was those last things in particular that
made me realize that, you know, more than just teaching people those skills
to how to lead happy lives, business could play
what did you do before that? - That background did quite different. At university, I studied business marketing.

I worked in marketing and finance
to, you know, for many different startups. - And you're also the founder of Hapzly.

- Mm-hmm. - Maybe just a few seconds on that. - Yeah. Well, just leading off to what I just said,
I saw that me maybe inadvertently

supporting businesses that didn't align to our
values and beliefs every single day, and that can have a huge impact
on a much grander scale.

So I realized the importance
of, you know, on the consumer level, being able to identify businesses that are fostering
and providing happiness so they can make clearer,

more informed choices that have a positive
impact, but also a tool for businesses to continually improve their happiness outcomes.

So I guess the challenge was to, you know,
to be able to define happiness and show that it

can be defined and it can be used as a tool to improve
businesses success, but also increase the happiness

of all the stakeholders, the community
environment, their employees, and things like that. - So we are here to talk about inclusivity
and how to make the world better.

And I know you're just here talk about,
and specifically about how

a company can become more happy. And a big part of that is that the employees
are more happy, and that it's also responsible.

So we have a lot of minorities in our
society and we want to give them, really, a fair chance to be a part
of what we do in our businesses.

There's a lot of time and money invested
in this space and there's a lot of debate.

How do you see that? Is that the…do we get enough
out of that time and money invested?

- Yeah, I can speak at least
from the, kind of, inclusion front. And if we're looking at the diversity reports that
are coming out and the updates to those reports,

we're seeing the needle is not moving the way
that we would hope it would be moving,

despite $8 billion in diversity trainings,
lots of chief diversity officers that we're hiring,

giving budgets to groups internally. And I think part of the problem is that we're not
actually treating this as a business problem,

the same way that we treat other business problems. We're not holding leaders accountable
for solving this problem, right?

And so, we continue to do the
same things over and over again. And I think some of that
comes down to power structures.

How do those of us who are in majority
groups actually confront our privilege,

confront our learned inherent racism,
or sexism, or ageism, or ableism,

everything that comes along with being
in a society that has power structures? And how do we start to admit that maybe we got
to where we are, sure, because we worked hard,

but also because there are things in society
that are set up to give us an advantage?

And so, doing this type of work is really hard
because it involves leadership actually confronting

the privilege that we have, and actually helping
people, giving them a little bit of a leg up.

And it feels weird to maybe think about we're
going to give extra attention or put extra effort

behind helping people who've been disadvantaged. Because I didn't get that extra effort or, you know,
maybe a white man in power didn't get that

extra effort when they were,
you know, in the more junior level.

And so, I think that's what
makes this problem really, really difficult. And we just have to…we have
to keep trying different things, right?

And it all has to be part of a comprehensive strategy. There are lots of studies that are showing
that there are certain things that we do

that don't work on their own. Unconscious bias training doesn't work on its own. But when unconscious bias training is
part of a more comprehensive effort,

comprehensive strategy that has leadership
support at the center of it and people are actually

held accountable and incentivized,
that's what starts to move the needle. So in short, it's just very difficult.

- I'm just interested in these new roles
that are popping up around diversity. What's the, like, the main aim of their role?

Are they hiring only or is it, you know,
researching these studies to find what's the best way to…

- It really depends on the company. So I have some friends who are more in the,
like, social sciences area who do get to do

a lot of this research, but then also,
you know, we have people who are solely focused on diversity hiring.

But then once you get people into the organization,
they're not happy, they burn out, right? And so, we really have to be
looking at this from all angles.

And I think the research part that
you bring up is pretty important because we still don't have a lot of research on this.

Like, we can't find studies that show
that ERGs help people get promoted. We can't find studies that
say that diversity trainings help.

And so, I think we're still kind of in the early
stages of figuring out how to tackle this problem. - Where do we start?

I mean, how do we make people engaged and how
do we make everyone feel important in a company?

What, I mean, where do we start? Because if you are in a minority group,
it's by default that you're not on the main track.

So the risk here is you being left behind. You being, like, set outside, like in the
schoolyard when you were young.
You know, if you're different, you were left outside. And this is kind of the circle we need to break.

So how can we break that negative circle? - I think there are several different
approaches and everybody's different, right?

And not everybody from a particular group is
going to feel oppressed in the same way, right?

And so in my job as a director, a lot
of what I put attention to was transparency,

upward feedback, making sure that
people knew that they can could come to me if they were having a problem with their manager.

And that was a culture on my team. My managers, who worked for me knew
that I was going to be having skip levels,

skip level meetings with people who worked for them. And I wanted to create sort of a culture of,
it's okay for us to give feedback to each other.

It's okay to call me out if I say something that
is excluding somebody, and it's safe to do so.

And so, I think there are a lot of things that we need
to do around making sure that leadership actually understands what is it like for frontline employees?

How do people feel when
they come into work every day? Are they happy? Do they, you know, do they enjoy coming into work?

And if they're not, is anybody listening to them? And that's really been the biggest
thing because I'm going to screw up.

I'm not going to do everything correctly. And so, I want people to be able to tell me
what needs to be fixed so that I can go fix it.

- Right. - Yeah. - You know, I think that's important in terms
of, she's just mentioned, in terms of people

being heard. Like, when our employees feel
useful and recognized, that's a big component

of meaning, and meaning is a fundamental
part for us to achieve happiness. And that leads directly onto more engaged
employees, right, when our voices are being heard

and we're playing a role in the decision making
or giving feedback, or the employees actually

understand our goals
as employees and working with them. I think that's important for them to feel recognized,
useful, and then, you know,

increase their positive emotions and then come back
to jobs and, you know, really want to push through.

- So you also talked about doing just
things that are not directly work-related.

So it could be like meditation, learning
about mindfulness, yoga, or exercise,

or whatever it is that is not directly work,
because maybe that's new to everyone,

or at least it's new to the people
in the group on a different level.

So you can kind of make everyone a little bit on new
ground and when they're there, they feel, oh, wow.

Maybe that's a minority person who are more
into mindfulness and the other one are all of a sudden

behind… You can kind of challenge everyone in a
different way than you do in normal work environments.

- I feel like just… - I mean, shake it at the waist. - In that example in terms of, like, mental
health programs and well-being programs,

it just shows that, you know, the spread
of care coming from the employer. And, you know, one of the benefits
of mindfulness and meditation, you know,

less stress and less anxiety and things
like that, but also, it, you know, creates more compassionate human
beings, and that's a fundamental

for empathy and belonging
and, you know, that kind of thing. That training, that social trust within the business,
which has a huge effect on our employees'

well-being and happiness and in most of, you know,
the success of the role and then where that takes them.

- So you say that a main factor for making
this work is reduce stress for everyone?

- Well, I think, like, on the sort of top-level,
I think when most people think about meditation,

especially from a business level, they
think of just reducing anxiety and stress. But, you know, the ripple effect is,
you know, goes well beyond that.

You know, it has a huge impact outside the
business in terms of the impact on their relationship

with their family, and their customers,
and all that kinds of things but also, you know, things like better concentration and all these other
things like problem solving and sharpness intuition,

which are all these things that, you know,
create better, happier employees, and engaged employees. - Yeah. - I think similar to this, I actually tell a
lot of people I work with to get into therapy

because I've been going to therapy and it's
been hugely helpful for me to work on myself

and to see some of the behaviors that
I do at home and in my personal life, and how those carry over into my professional life.

And I think one thing that's really important
for leaders especially is for us to just be self-aware and to always be working on ourselves
and to be improving ourselves in some ways.

I think a lot of us get stuck in this, you
know, "We're successful and we got here because everything's been, you know,
because everything I've been doing has been great."

But really, I want people to be always thinking
about how they can grow and how they can improve.

- Yeah. I think I mentioned that in just my talk. We run so fast we can forget people
around us, people two feet from us

experiencing every kind of emotion. And then when we implement little tools
like this, it can increase empathy in businesses

and understanding which then has a
huge ripple effect for the minority groups and also for, you know,
as you go up to the managers.

- And you were talking about the same thing,
like, understanding yourself, like, really…

- You know, understanding yourself is
imperative to then understand others. - Exactly. - Empathy. - Yeah. And open your mind.

When you understand yourself then you
can open your mind and you are more, you know, receptive to be inclusive,
and not just look for people like yourself.

- Yeah. So maybe when it comes to this,
it is about training people on these other skills to really develop these things around compassion
that can then have a huge impact

on how they're treating employees. - Yeah. I did a bunch of interviews
with people across our tech organization,

and I was asking people,
"What do you want in a manager?" And the words that kept coming up were
kindness and empathy and compassion.

"I want a manager who understands me." So compassion is actually a word
that came into our management principles.

And we're thinking about how do we actually
get people to build that EQ muscle over time?

- So you probably know Kim Scott, both of you? - Mm-hmm. - There's one thing I
like about her book, "Radical Candor."

And that is when we are in a job situation,
we have to be…it's a personal thing.

We cannot treat people like professionals
because we've spent so much time together that

we actually become a family, and in a family,
feelings and emotions are important.

So, her point is, like, it doesn't help
that you have a relationship with your

leader and employee, and that you have like, "Oh,
I'll just keep it on a professional level," you know?

That's wrong success because it is actually
about a relationship between two people,
and that's about emotions. So you have to work with that. You have to accept that.

And that's scary to many managers that they have
to…now they're all of a sudden more than just

someone who tells someone what to do and give
feedback and say, "Oh, you did pretty well." Now it's about listening to problems
and handling the situations.

- Yeah, that's how it should be, right? These employees as just human beings after all and… - Exactly, but that's not what's
happening, you know…

- Yeah, it's cool. - Okay. So that leads to a question of how important
is leadership in this and the top management

and how do you engage a
basic management in the company? And you mentioned founders before,
you mentioned that you actually
went to the founders of the company. How important is that and how can you do it?

- Yeah. I think it's really important for leadership
to signal what their values and their beliefs are

because that's very important to a lot
of people when they decide where to work. And it's really important to me in terms
of where I decide to invest my time.

And I think we can't really do
much without getting leadership involved.

A lot of the inclusion work when you look
at, like, diversity labor and inclusion labor,

its happening with underrepresented
employees who are not well-represented in leadership and management roles.

And a lot of them feel like, "I have
no choice but to advocate for myself. If I don't advocate for myself
and my community, who will?"

Right? And so, without the help of majority
groups and without the help of leadership, the people with actual authority in your organizations
to shift your culture or to state what your values are,

and to actually choose where
to invest time and resources, it's very, very difficult to make
any meaningful progress on this.

And so, there are lots of studies that show
without that engagement from top leadership,

it's really difficult to move the needle. - And how, you know, so you
tried to make Hapzly a bigger company,

and so do you have any experience on how
you approach your potential customers?

And, at what level, I mean, what works,
I mean, how do you approach…?

- You know, I did test, as you said, like,
founders or leaders who are forward-thinking

and compassionate individuals first
and foremost to make these big changes. Like, that's how you and I met.

You know, you're someone who, you know,
really thinks about the happiness of your employees and also your environmental impact.

So it takes people like you who are
in those positions to make a shift. It's like Patagonia which has
now flourished as a company

based on its focus on the
environment and sustainability. But it took Yvon Chouinard, who is the founder,
to, you know, to grant 1% for the planet,

where he started, you know, donating 1% of profits
to carefully chosen environmental nonprofits. And then when a big company like that is doing it
and then the other companies start, you know,

getting on board too because they've
seen the positive impact it has not only on the environment,
but also on their business.

And I think it has to come back
to how it benefits the business. I think that there are huge benefits for business,
and I think that's why it needs to be,

you know, put into the spotlight. - I actually bought a Patagonia ski jacket
the other day, and the sales guy,

he understood the values of the
company, which is not always the case when you buy something,
but he actually understood it.

And he taught me about the values
of the company, and, he really stressed that,

whatever happens to your jacket, just come
in, we will repair it, so you don't have to worry.

We will make the lifespan
of this jacket, you know, very long.
- And that creates loyalty. - Yeah. And I really liked that, you know, so, yeah.

- And it all started like, you know,
starting with Patagonia, now it's all, like, it's becoming the norm. Like, other companies are starting to do that.

- Yeah. They're copying them. - And that's kind of where they see the huge
success they're having especially, you know,

the amount of loyalty amongst the
consumers and their employees, and then other companies are
like, "Oh, we need to start doing this too."

- So talking about HR, now we talk
about management, middle management
and… So what is your view on HR? How can they help this situation?

- HR has been a huge partner to me
in pretty much everything that I've done,

whether that's our diversity inclusion
group or simply our HR business partners.

Those are the people who are, you know,
meant to be in service to the employees, of course.

And we hear this phrase that HR is there
to protect the company and not to protect

the employees, and I
understand where that comes from. And there is, like, a little bit of truth behind that.

But also, you know, a good HR person is going
to protect the company by protecting the employees.

And so, for me, it's really important that I
have a good relationship with my HR team and that I know who to go to, especially
when I start to hear little concerns,

and hearing them before they become
big concerns, and knowing where to take them. A lot of the work that I do has implications
on our HR processes and our systems.

And so, I want to make sure that we're all on board
because ultimately, we do want the same things, right?

We do want engaged and happy workforces. We don't want to lead to escalations all the
time and we certainly don't want to see

big problems show up in the news. We'd like to address them early. And so, it's really been important to me to engage HR
really early in anything that I'm trying to embark

on because sometimes
I can go off the rails a little bit. - Yeah. Obviously, that's, you know, a huge impact.

The choices that they make in who
they hire and what they do not only changes their business,
but changes the world, fundamentally.

- Okay. So what are the biggest challenges
minority groups face at companies today?

Any thought on that? - Yeah. I would really point people to the Tech Leavers Study
that the Kapor Center for Social Impact did.
It came out, I think in 2017. It's very different per group. So black women getting passed over for promotions,

LGBT employees getting bullied
or harassed in the workplace. So it's very dependent.

And again, not everybody feels
oppression in the same way. One thing that I tend to think about is that we can't
point to, like, the smoking gun in these situations.

And so, there's this concept
of death by a thousand paper cuts. It would be one thing if somebody could just
tell us, "This is the problem in the organization,"

and somebody who can go fix it. But instead, it's an engineer who maybe one
day is mistaken for recruiting or janitorial staff

or kitchen staff, and then the next day
it's being talked over in a meeting. And the next day, it's having
someone steal your idea.

The next day it's being told you're too vocal,
and the next day being told you're not vocal enough. All of these things, you can maybe look
at in isolation and explain them away.

Or, you know, "Oh, this person had really good
intentions," but what we don't actually get a sense

for is how that feels over time and how it
starts to build up and how it starts to make

people feel isolated and excluded. And I think that's part of what makes this so difficult
is how do we actually deal with all of these

little microaggressions, and the isms,
and the things that are, you know,

very difficult to deal with in the world, and now
we have to deal with them in our workplace. So I think that's really what
makes this seem so intractable.

- What do you see in your…? - Well, I guess it goes back
to what we discussed before. The important factor of education, because it is like,
you know, these things we're seeing in the world

is the same as what we're
seeing inside the business now. So educating people, really making
sure our employees are developing
the skills around compassion and empathy. I think that's a good start. And to help get over the obstacles that they're facing.

I don't know firsthand experience as much as Jill
in terms of your day-to-day, things like that,

but I guess it starts by teaching
people those tools and, you know. - What can you then do to actually help the situation?

I mean, do you have some tips
and tricks that can get the ball rolling? Because we've talked a lot about the
problems and how it feels and all this stuff,

but maybe just some really good ideas that you
can pass on to the audience so they can just

get going and get the ball rolling
and be more happy as a business and have their employees more engaged.

I mean, what are, like,
the top three tips you can give? - You can go.

- I think the first thing is being aware of what
an employee needs to be happy in the first place,

you know, and how businesses can influence those
elements in terms of like time use and living standards

and you have workplaces that
nurture positivity and well-being, and actually caring for the health of these employees.

So I think once we're aware of those
elements, then we can see how the business can actually influence them.

So things like when you look at time use,
it could be implementing things like flexibility

into the workplace, and that can deepen
that culture and that high trust culture,

which is important for your business success. When you're looking at what
an individual needs to be happy, they need to be able to develop
themselves personally and professionally.

So we can implement things into our employees to,
you know, to keep on improving their skills,

to add to their existing skills
to learn things like values and ethics. And we can also have them involved in, you know,
the decision-making process and actually have their

voice heard because that, you know,
is directly in line to them being able to develop

personally and professionally and also that
engagement and deepening that meaning and that recognition and that usefulness.

So there's just two simple things I think
that come on the back of being aware of how we can influence that employees' happiness.

- I would plus one, everything that you said. I might also add that there's some interesting ideas
around, if you're familiar with the term "ombudsman."

That's, like, a third party that's meant to hear
concerns and sort of help people navigate

and, you know, figure out how
to actually resolve an escalation.

And so, there's a company called tEQuitable
that is like this third-party organization

and employees can think about these paper cuts. Employees can actually anonymously report these
issues that are happening in their workplace

because they're happening all the time,
we just don't hear about them because it seems like such a nuclear option to go to, like,
escalate something so small to HR.

But to make sure that we're actually capturing
what is it like, and then to be able to see

those patterns, it's hard to see those patterns
when you're talking about minority groups, like, small tiny numbers in your organizations.

Giving people an outlet for how to raise their
concerns, and for them to be able to say, "I don't need you to make a big deal
out of this, but I want someone to be aware

that it's happening so that once we start
to see the patterns, we can address it." - That's definitely important.

Because otherwise, those little things
just become always overlooked, and then you never really see those patterns.

- How do we start changing all this? I mean, what would you do
tomorrow, basically, is my question.

What can we go home, or just
right after this video is over then people

to think, okay, what should they do right after? I mean, what's the most important
thing they can just get going on?

- One of the things I said in my talk
is if you don't know where to start, go address your underrepresented people,
and pick a process, pick something that is opaque

to them that we probably think is working. "Let me explain how it works
to you and then let me just listen,"

when people say, "That's not how it works for me." And that has generally told us where
we need to focus our attention.

And so, when we hear things, right now,
one of the things that we're trying to take on,

we have a diversity working group that is
led mostly by managers and directors.
So that's who's doing all of the work. And we're talking about team switches.

And how do team switches work? What does a manager handoff look like? And I want to know, what is the actual
experience of our underrepresented people?

What's holding them back from switching teams? What about the process has been frustrating to them? And that's going to tell us where
we need to focus our efforts.

We don't actually have the answers. As far as we're concerned,
everything's working just fine. But I've heard enough, you know,
there's little struggles here and there that

I think it's important to sort of get everybody
in a room, allow them to feed off of each other, and make that environment safe for people to speak
up and tell us, what do we need to go address?

- I think an important thing is to realize that,
you know, these things actually make business better.

And once we are aware of those things,
then we're probably more likely to do it. And then, you know, again, asking
questions and listening and actually creating

that awareness individually first, and then, you
know, burst the bubble, you have to be aware

of what things are happening first
to be able to address them. - So how important is it to really understand the
values of the company you work in to achieve

better inclusivity and happiness? - I think, you know, the choices we make
as to where we work or who we hire

and what we wear and buy and eat and, you
know, who are our suppliers and everything, then we'll have a rippling effect
throughout all of the business and society

and the ecosystems and everything, right? So basically, every time you make a choice, where choosing to, you know, have
no impact or have a positive impact.

So, you know, yeah, super important. - Yeah, for me, you know, I think almost
every company is talking about how much

they care about diversity and inclusion. Most companies are starting
to put some money behind it,

but that doesn't necessarily
mean that they actually care. And so, it's really important for me to listen to my
backchannel to, like, view the actions of companies,

because I know this work is
really hard and I constantly

have to, I feel like I'm swimming upstream sometimes. And so, it's very important that I know that
the entire management chain above me,

that we're all working towards a common goal
because if we're not, I'm just going to hit roadblock after roadblock.

But when we have the same values and we
can actually have discussions about what

approaches we want to take and, you know,
I'm not going to be right about everything, but I want to make sure that
we're marching towards the same goals.

And I also think in terms of the companies that we
support, I think if we really care about, you know,

racial equality, and I care about it in my
organization, I also care about it in my community.

I want to invest my money in black and Latin X
businesses, in women-owned businesses

because ultimately, these might be businesses
that I want to work for one day, right? And so, I think it's really important that we do
put our money where our values are as well.

- That's important. And I know… - I was going to say we would like to know we can
connect with our values in all areas of our lives.

- And Evan, you would like to see a
chief happiness officer in every company?

- I definitely did it and, you know, if it
aligns with those companies' values and if it sort of can connect the dots in a holistic
way and can make the business better.

And yeah, sometimes we, you know,
we have people who look after sustainability and that's all, and sometimes we have
people who look after employee well-being,
